py-tidymodels
  • py-workflows: Pipeline Composition
  • View page source

py-workflows: Pipeline Composition

The py_workflows package provides tools for composing preprocessing + model + postprocessing into unified workflows.

Core Classes

class py_workflows.Workflow(preprocessor=None, spec=None, post=None, case_weights=None, model_name=None, model_group_name=None)[source]

Bases: object

Immutable workflow composition.

Workflows combine preprocessing (formula or recipe) with a model specification into a single pipeline that can be fitted and used for prediction.

preprocessor

Formula string or Recipe object (or None)

spec

ModelSpec for the model to fit

post

Post-processing steps (future use)

case_weights

Column name for case weights (optional)

model_name

Optional name for the model (used in extract_outputs())

model_group_name

Optional group name for organizing models (used in extract_outputs())

Examples

>>> # Create workflow with formula and model
>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_formula("sales ~ price + advertising")
...     .add_model(linear_reg().set_engine("sklearn"))
...     .add_model_name("baseline")
...     .add_model_group_name("linear_models")
... )
>>>
>>> # Fit workflow
>>> wf_fit = wf.fit(train_data)
>>>
>>> # Predict on new data
>>> predictions = wf_fit.predict(test_data)
>>>
>>> # Extract outputs with custom model names
>>> outputs, _, _ = wf_fit.extract_outputs()
>>> print(outputs["model"].unique())  # ['baseline']
>>> print(outputs["model_group_name"].unique())  # ['linear_models']
preprocessor: Optional[Any] = None
spec: Optional[ModelSpec] = None
post: Optional[Any] = None
case_weights: Optional[str] = None
model_name: Optional[str] = None
model_group_name: Optional[str] = None
add_formula(formula)[source]

Add a formula for preprocessing.

Parameters:

formula (str) R-style formula string (e.g., y ~ x1 + x2)

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

New Workflow with formula added

Raises:

ValueError If workflow already has a preprocessor

Examples

>>> wf = workflow().add_formula("sales ~ price + advertising")
add_model(spec)[source]

Add a model specification.

Parameters:

spec (ModelSpec) ModelSpec instance (from linear_reg(), rand_forest(), etc.)

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

New Workflow with model added

Raises:

ValueError If workflow already has a model

Examples

>>> wf = workflow().add_model(linear_reg().set_engine("sklearn"))
add_recipe(recipe)[source]

Add a recipe for preprocessing.

Parameters:

recipe (Any) Recipe object with preprocessing steps

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

New Workflow with recipe added

Raises:

ValueError If workflow already has a preprocessor

Examples

>>> from py_recipes import recipe
>>> rec = recipe().step_normalize().step_dummy(["category"])
>>> wf = workflow().add_recipe(rec).add_model(linear_reg())
add_model_name(name)[source]

Add a model name for identification in outputs.

The model name will appear in the model column of DataFrames returned by extract_outputs().

Parameters:

name (str) Name for this model (e.g., baseline, poly, interaction)

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

New Workflow with model_name set

Examples

>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_model(linear_reg())
...     .add_model_name("baseline")
... )
>>> fit = wf.fit(train_data)
>>> outputs, _, _ = fit.extract_outputs()
>>> print(outputs["model"].unique())  # ['baseline']
add_model_group_name(group_name)[source]

Add a model group name for organizing related models.

The model group name will appear in the model_group_name column of DataFrames returned by extract_outputs(). Useful for organizing models into logical groups (e.g., linear_models, tree_models, ensemble).

Parameters:

group_name (str) Group name for organizing models (e.g., linear_models, polynomial)

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

New Workflow with model_group_name set

Examples

>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_model(linear_reg())
...     .add_model_name("baseline")
...     .add_model_group_name("linear_models")
... )
>>> fit = wf.fit(train_data)
>>> outputs, _, _ = fit.extract_outputs()
>>> print(outputs["model_group_name"].unique())  # ['linear_models']

fit(data)[source]

Fit the entire workflow to training data.

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) Training data DataFrame

Return type:

WorkflowFit

Returns:

WorkflowFit object containing fitted pipeline

Raises:

ValueError If workflow doesnt have a model

Examples

>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_formula("sales ~ price")
...     .add_model(linear_reg().set_engine("sklearn"))
... )
>>> wf_fit = wf.fit(train_data)
fit_nested(data, group_col, per_group_prep=True, min_group_size=30, n_jobs=None, verbose=False)[source]

Fit separate models for each group in the data (panel/grouped modeling).

This method fits one independent model per group value, useful for: - Multi-store sales forecasting (one model per store) - Multi-product demand forecasting (one model per product) - Multi-region time series (one model per region)

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) Training data DataFrame with group column

  • group_col (str) Column name containing group identifiers

  • per_group_prep (bool) If True, prep recipe separately for each group. Enables group-specific feature engineering (PCA, feature selection). Default: True (each group gets optimized preprocessing).

  • min_group_size (int) Minimum samples required for per-group preprocessing. Groups smaller than this use global recipe (if per_group_prep=True). Default: 30.

  • n_jobs (Optional[int]) Number of parallel jobs. None or 1 for sequential execution, -1 for all CPU cores, or positive integer for specific number of cores.

  • verbose (bool) If True, display progress messages

Return type:

NestedWorkflowFit

Returns:

NestedWorkflowFit containing dict of fitted models per group

Raises:

ValueError If group_col not in data or workflow doesnt have model

Examples

>>> # Fit separate models for each store (shared preprocessing)
>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_formula("sales ~ date")
...     .add_model(recursive_reg(base_model=rand_forest(), lags=7))
... )
>>> nested_fit = wf.fit_nested(data, group_col="store_id")
>>>
>>> # Fit with parallel execution
>>> nested_fit = wf.fit_nested(data, group_col="store_id", n_jobs=-1, verbose=True)
>>>
>>> # Fit with per-group feature engineering (e.g., PCA)
>>> wf_pca = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_recipe(recipe().step_pca(num_comp=5))
...     .add_model(linear_reg())
... )
>>> nested_fit = wf_pca.fit_nested(
...     data,
...     group_col="store_id",
...     per_group_prep=True,  # Each group gets own PCA components
...     n_jobs=4  # Use 4 cores
... )
>>>
>>> # Predict for all groups
>>> predictions = nested_fit.predict(test_data)
>>> # Extract outputs with group column
>>> outputs, coeffs, stats = nested_fit.extract_outputs()
fit_global(data, group_col)[source]

Fit a single global model using group as a feature.

This method fits one model using all groups together, with the group column as an additional predictor. Useful when: - Groups share common patterns - Insufficient data per group for separate models - Want to capture cross-group effects

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) Training data DataFrame with group column

  • group_col (str) Column name containing group identifiers (used as feature)

Return type:

WorkflowFit

Returns:

WorkflowFit with group column included as predictor

Raises:

ValueError If group_col not in data or workflow doesnt have model

Examples

>>> # Fit single model using store_id as a feature
>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_formula("sales ~ date + store_id")
...     .add_model(rand_forest())
... )
>>> global_fit = wf.fit_global(data, group_col="store_id")
>>>
>>> # Group column is automatically included as predictor
>>> predictions = global_fit.predict(test_data)
__init__(preprocessor=None, spec=None, post=None, case_weights=None, model_name=None, model_group_name=None)
class py_workflows.WorkflowFit(workflow, pre, fit, post=None, formula=None, recipe_prepped_without_outcome=False, is_global_fit=False, group_col=None, _train_group_values=None, _test_group_values=None)[source]

Bases: object

Fitted workflow containing preprocessing and model fit.

workflow

Original Workflow specification

pre

Fitted preprocessor (formula or recipe)

fit

ModelFit object from parsnip

post

Post-processing steps (future use)

formula

Formula used for model fitting (stored for convenience)

recipe_prepped_without_outcome

Whether recipe was prepped excluding outcome column

Examples

>>> wf_fit = workflow().add_formula("y ~ x").add_model(spec).fit(train)
>>> predictions = wf_fit.predict(test)
>>> outputs, coeffs, stats = wf_fit.extract_outputs()

predict(new_data, type='numeric')[source]

Generate predictions using the fitted workflow.

Automatically applies preprocessing before prediction.

Parameters:

  • new_data (DataFrame) New data for prediction

  • type (str) Prediction type (numeric, conf_int, pred_int, etc.)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with predictions

Examples

>>> predictions = wf_fit.predict(test_data)
>>> # With prediction intervals
>>> predictions = wf_fit.predict(test_data, type="pred_int")
evaluate(test_data, outcome_col=None)[source]

Evaluate workflow on test data.

Stores test predictions for comprehensive train/test metrics.

Parameters:

  • test_data (DataFrame) Test data with actual outcomes

  • outcome_col (Optional[str]) Name of outcome column (auto-detected if None)

Return type:

WorkflowFit

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> wf_fit = wf.fit(train).evaluate(test)
>>> outputs, coeffs, stats = wf_fit.extract_outputs()
>>> # Now outputs includes both train and test observations

extract_outputs()[source]

Extract comprehensive three-DataFrame outputs.

Return type:

Tuple[DataFrame, DataFrame, DataFrame]

Returns:

Tuple of (outputs, coefficients, stats) DataFrames per .claude_plans/model_outputs.md specification

Examples

>>> outputs, coefficients, stats = wf_fit.extract_outputs()
>>>
>>> # Outputs: observation-level results
>>> print(outputs[["actuals", "fitted", "forecast", "split"]])
>>>
>>> # Coefficients: variable-level parameters
>>> print(coefficients[["variable", "coefficient", "p_value"]])
>>>
>>> # Stats: model-level metrics by split
>>> print(stats[stats["metric"].isin(["rmse", "mae", "r_squared"])])
extract_formula()[source]

Extract the formula used for model fitting.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Formula string (e.g., y ~ x1 + x2)

Examples

>>> wf_fit = workflow().add_formula("sales ~ price").add_model(spec).fit(train)
>>> formula = wf_fit.extract_formula()
>>> print(formula)
'sales ~ price'
>>>
>>> # For recipes, returns auto-generated formula
>>> rec = recipe().step_normalize()
>>> wf_fit = workflow().add_recipe(rec).add_model(spec).fit(train)
>>> formula = wf_fit.extract_formula()
>>> print(formula)
'y ~ x1 + x2 + x3'
extract_preprocessed_data(data)[source]

Apply the fitted preprocessor to data and return transformed data.

This is a convenience function to get the preprocessed data that would be used by the model, useful for: - Inspecting transformed features - Understanding what the model actually sees - Debugging preprocessing pipelines - Manual analysis of transformed data

Parameters:

data (DataFrame) Data to preprocess (train or test data)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with preprocessing applied

Examples

>>> # With formula
>>> wf_fit = workflow().add_formula("y ~ x1 + x2").add_model(spec).fit(train)
>>> train_transformed = wf_fit.extract_preprocessed_data(train)
>>> test_transformed = wf_fit.extract_preprocessed_data(test)
>>>
>>> # With recipe
>>> rec = recipe().step_normalize().step_dummy()
>>> wf_fit = workflow().add_recipe(rec).add_model(spec).fit(train)
>>> train_transformed = wf_fit.extract_preprocessed_data(train)
>>>
>>> # Inspect transformed columns
>>> print(train_transformed.columns)
>>> print(train_transformed.head())
__init__(workflow, pre, fit, post=None, formula=None, recipe_prepped_without_outcome=False, is_global_fit=False, group_col=None, _train_group_values=None, _test_group_values=None)

Main Functions

py_workflows.workflow()[source]

Create a new empty workflow.

Return type:

Workflow

Returns:

Empty Workflow ready for composition

Examples

>>> wf = (
...     workflow()
...     .add_formula("sales ~ price + advertising")
...     .add_model(linear_reg(penalty=0.1).set_engine("sklearn"))
... )
>>> wf_fit = wf.fit(train_data)

Examples

Basic Workflow

from py_workflows import workflow
from py_parsnip import linear_reg

# Create workflow
wf = (
    workflow()
    .add_formula("sales ~ price + advertising")
    .add_model(linear_reg())
)

# Fit and evaluate
wf_fit = wf.fit(train_data)
wf_fit = wf_fit.evaluate(test_data)

# Extract outputs
outputs, coefs, stats = wf_fit.extract_outputs()

Method Chaining

# Full pipeline in one chain
outputs, coefs, stats = (
    workflow()
    .add_formula("y ~ x1 + x2 + x3")
    .add_model(linear_reg().set_engine("sklearn"))
    .fit(train_data)
    .evaluate(test_data)
    .extract_outputs()
)

Panel/Grouped Models

from py_workflows import workflow
from py_parsnip import recursive_reg, rand_forest

# Nested approach: separate model per group
wf = (
    workflow()
    .add_formula("sales ~ lag1 + lag2 + lag3")
    .add_model(recursive_reg(base_model=rand_forest(), lags=7))
)

nested_fit = wf.fit_nested(data, group_col="store_id")
predictions = nested_fit.predict(test_data)
outputs, coefs, stats = nested_fit.extract_outputs()

# Global approach: single model with group as feature
global_fit = wf.fit_global(data, group_col="store_id")
predictions = global_fit.predict(test_data)

Extracting Components

# Fit workflow
wf_fit = workflow().add_formula("y ~ x").add_model(linear_reg()).fit(train_data)

# Extract components
model_fit = wf_fit.extract_fit_parsnip()
preprocessor = wf_fit.extract_preprocessor()
model_spec = wf_fit.extract_spec_parsnip()

# Access underlying engine model
sklearn_model = model_fit.extract_fit_engine()
